comments:
Tested on RSD Release build 20080831_0527
CDT version 3.1.1.200608070800

Import some C++ code into a C++ managed make project. This code builds perfectly OK. There are no error messages.

Save the project, Close the project then reopen the application. 

Re-open RSD.

Re-open the project -> get the following message: " The project build settings are stored in a format that is no longer supported (version 2.0.0) Would you like to convert it to the newer version (3.0.0)? 

If you select 'yes', you get the following error - "The managed make project file could not be written because of the following error: Could not write file: C:\path_name\.cdtbuild. " 

Press OK to remove dialogs. Then everything builds fine.

Created an attachment (id=49210)
CPP project , zip file

Unzip the attached file and import into C++ Managed project.
Open the project, then close the project, reopen the project and you will receive error messages. 

Log file reads:

!MESSAGE Skipping builder com.ibm.sse.model.structuredbuilder for project CPP Project. Either the builder is missing from the install, or it belongs to a project nature that is missing or disabled.
This would be a build issue.
This is 100% reproducable, although I don't get the log entry. Also, the version is now 3.1.0 (was this a typo?).

(In reply to comment #3)
> This is 100% reproducable, although I don't get the log entry. Also, the
> version is now 3.1.0 (was this a typo?).

Yes that was a typo, sorry.

The .cdtbuild file of the sample project contains the "hidden" flag set. If you remove that flag, everything will work fine.

The root cause of the issue is that the Managed Build Info gets accessed before the project tree gets loadded into the workspace.
E.g. the workspace refresh that is performed after the project import is performed after the project build request is performed (when autobuild is on).
As a result the .cdtbuild file is not seen at that time.
The .cdtbuild file load is performed using standard java File API, while the file store (initiated by the project update mechanism in the sample project) is performed via eclipse IResource API.
The Managed Build Info serialization logic examines whether the .cdtbuild file exists in the workspace and if not, tries to create the one using the IFile.create(). The method fails in case the underlying resource exists and is "hidden".

Sometime ago I raised a bug against the platform regarding the project-scoped preferences inaccessibility from OPEN event handler on project import (see bug# 139911). The root cause of that problem was the same as the one for this bug.
The bug was closed as WONTFIX.

I'm not sure whether invoking build before importing(refreshing) the complete project tree stands within eclipse build ideology. I'm going to raise a bug againts platform to get more clarification on this.

The quick solution for this bug for now could be to use java File API for storing the build info.
This would make the build info load/store mechanism consistent since both would use one and the same mechanism for accessing the .cdtbuild file.

Thoughts?

Mikhail

(In reply to comment #5)
BTW, I see the error message right after the project import, not after I close and re-open it.

Mikhail

-1 on using java.io. We'll need to support projects on EFS, so by passing IResource is bad.

Since there is a workaround, I'll move it off the 3.1.1 list. Thanks for looking into this Mikhail.
